questions.question: A 23-year-old lady presents with the lesions shown below. What is the causative organism?
questions.explanation: The presentation of lesions is most commonly associated with Herpes simplex virus type 1.

questions.question: Cowdry Type A inclusions are seen in:
questions.explanation: Cowdry type A inclusions are seen in the vesicles of Herpes Simplex infectionThe classic Cowdry type A inclusion appears as a light purple, homogeneous intranuclearstructure surrounded by a clear halo. The inclusions stain with antibodies to HSV, permitting arapid, specific diagnosis of HSV infection.361HSV inclusion bodiesOMARROW

questions.question: 351A 13-year-old girl has had 4 episodes of meningitis over the last 4 years, with the diseaselasting a few days at a time, leaving slowly resolving neurological symptoms such as visualand memory loss. A CSF cytology shows lymphocytic pleocytosis and a diagnosis of Mollaret'smeningitis is made. Which organism is implicated here?
questions.explanation: Mollaret's meningitis or benign recurrent lymphocytic meningitis is most commonly caused bythe herpes simplex virus (HSV). Demonstration of HSV antibodies in CSF or persistence of HSVDNA in CSF can establish the diagnosis.

questions.question: A dentist presents to the surgery OPD with the findings shown below. He is febrile.Microscopic examination of the tissue reveals Tzanck cells. What is the causative agent?
questions.explanation: The image suggests herpetic whitlow, confirmed by the presence of Tzanck cells on microscopy. Itis caused by HSV-1.It is often contracted by health care workers that come in contact with the virus when exposed tooral secretions.On Tzanck smear, which is a rapid, diagnostic method, Tzanck cells are seen. These aremultinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogenously stained ground-glasschromatin. Tzanck smear is also used in the diagnosis of Hailey-Hailey disease, Darier's disease,hand-foot-and-mouth disease, etc.362Tzanck smearOMARROWDiagnosis of herpes simplex virus:• Most sensitive test- HSV DNA- PCR (can differentiate between HSV 1 and 2)•Most definitive test- virus isolation using human diploid fibroblast in which cytopathic changescan be observed as early as 24-48 hours.• Microscopy - Tzanck smear is prepared by Wright or Giemsa stain. Intranuclear type A inclusionbodies may be seen in Giemsa-stained smears.

questions.question: A young male presents to the STD clinic with painful lesions as shown in the image. What isthe most likely microscopic finding of the lesion?352

options.B: Pund cellsHenderson-Patterson bodiesd) Guarnieri bodiesQuestion 6:Your neighbor's child complains of fever and develops a rash. On examination, the rashes arepresent all over the body, and look like 'dewdrops lying on the skin'. The child says that hisfriend in school had similar complaints a few days ago. Which of the given statements is trueabout this rash?a) It is centripetal in distributionb) The rash usually starts on the distal parts of limbs
options.C: All the lesions are of same age
options.D: Scabs are also infectious in chicken pox

questions.explanation: Clusters of vesicles are seen on an erythematous base along with painful and pruriticlymphadenopathy suggest a diagnosis of genital herpes. Tzanck cells or multinucleated giant cellsare present on microscopy.The Tzanck smear is a rapid, sensitive, and inexpensive diagnostic method. Smears are preparedfrom the lesions, from the base of vesicles, and stained with a 1% aqueous solution of O-toluidineblue for 15 seconds. Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneouslystained ground glass chromatin - Tzanck cells are seen.The typical herpes lesions are thin-walled, umbilicated vesicles, the roof of which breaks down,leaving tiny superficial ulcers. They heal without scarring. The most common site of cutaneouslesions in the face - on the cheeks, chin, around the mouth, or on the forehead.363Tzanck smearOMARROW

questions.question: While on rounds in the NICU, you notice a newborn baby with a zig-zag dermatomal cicatrixon the forehead and left side of the face. The limbs are small and atrophied. Microcephaly isnoted. Which maternal infection are these findings characteristically associated with?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of congenital varicella syndrome. Hence, an antenatalhistory of varicella zoster virus (VZV) infection would be significant in the mother of this baby.Fetal varicella infection occurs if the mother gets infected during the first half of pregnancy.Clinical features include:• Cicatrix, a zigzag scarring in a dermatomal distribution• Microphthalmia• Cataracts• Optic atrophy• Chorioretinitis• Microcephaly• Limb hypoplasia• Motor and sensory deficits

questions.question: Which of the following is the predominant pathogen to infect renal transplant recipients oneto four months following transplantation?
questions.explanation: The predominant pathogen to infect renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV).The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients are fever (common),leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia.JC virus and BK virus are common infections after solid organ transplantation based on the site ofinfection. This means BK and JC viruses are the most common organisms to infect the kidneyafter any solid organ transplant. But CMV is the predominant organism to cause infection in aperson who has undergone a renal transplant. (Not the most common organism to affect thekidney after any solid organ transplant).Because of the frequency and severity of CMV disease, antiviral prophylaxis with ganciclovir orvalganciclovir is being used in renal transplant recipients whenever indicated to prevent CMVdisease.

questions.question: An infant is brought by his worried parents with a rash and yellowish discoloration of theskin. On examination, the baby has petechiae, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, andmicrocephaly. The developmental assessment shows global developmental delay. An axial cutof the non-contrast CT of the brain is given below. What is the causative organism?
questions.explanation: The clinical features and imaging suggest a diagnosis of congenital CMV infection. Thenon-contrast CT head shows periventricular calcifications and ventriculomegaly.Features of congenital CMV infection:• Petechial rash•Jaundice365• Hepatosplenomegaly•⚫ Microcephaly• Deafness•Chorioretinitis• IUGR• Periventricular calcification and ventriculomegaly©MARROWPeriventricularcalcificationsVentriculomegalyOption A: Congenital rubella syndrome is a triad of cardiac defects, cataracts, andcongenital hearing loss.Option B: Neonatal herpes presents as skin lesions with eye involvement, encephalitis, anddisseminated disease.Option D: Fetal varicella syndrome is manifested as cicatrizing/scarring skin lesions,chorioretinitis, hypoplastic limbs, low birth weight, and CNS defects due to cerebral atrophy.Note: In 15-20% of infants with congenital CMV infection, microcephaly is not detected at birth. Itmay develop as the child grows and is detected at follow-up visits for other complaints.

questions.question: Choose the correct statement regarding CMV.

options.A: Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene
options.B: CMV can be cultured in vitro in any mammalian cell
options.C: Commonest manifestation of CMV associated disease is watery diarrhea
options.D: UL54 mutated CMV strains do not show cross resistance to Foscarnet

questions.explanation: Resistance to ganciclovir most commonly occurs due to mutations in the UL97phosphotransferase gene.Option B: Human CMV replicates in vitro only in human fibroblasts, although the virus is oftenisolated from epithelial cells of the host.Option C: CMV infection is mostly subclinical.Option D: UL54 mutations can confer resistance to ganciclovir, cidofovir, and foscarnet.366

questions.question: Where are owl's eye inclusion bodies seen?
questions.explanation: Owl's eye inclusion bodies are intranuclear basophilic inclusion bodies seen in CMV infection.Owl eye inclusions inCytomegalovirus infectionOMARROW

questions.question: What does the Paul-Bunnell test diagnose?
questions.explanation: Paul-Bunnell test is used to diagnose kissing disease (infectious mononucleosis) caused byEpstein-Barr virus (EBV).It is a heterophile agglutination test used to identify the heterophile antibodies that agglutinatesheep erythrocytes. Patients suffering from infectious mononucleosis due to Epstein-Barr virus(EBV) will produce antibodies that will react and agglutinate sheep erythrocytes.

questions.question: You are studying the association of human herpesvirus-4 with other diseases. Which of thefollowing patients have diseases associated with this virus?
questions.explanation: Human herpesvirus-4 or Epstein-Barr virus causes infectious mononucleosis, Burkitt's lymphoma,and is associated with oral hairy leukoplakia in HIV patients.EBV may cause the following malignancies:•Burkitt's lymphoma•Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (in people of Chinese origin),• Lymphomas in immunodeficient persons such as AIDS or transplant recipients.Endemic or African Burkitt's lymphoma has got nearly 100% association with EBV, as comparedto non-endemic and HIV-associated Burkitt's lymphoma.Oral hairy leukoplakia is triggered by EBV in patients with poor immune status, most commonlywith HIV.Oral submucous fibrosis is associated with the human papillomavirus (HPV).367Adult T cell leukemia is associated with the human T-cell leukemia virus.

questions.question: Which of the following viruses is known to cause hemorrhagic cystitis, diarrhea, andconjunctivitis?
questions.explanation: Adenovirus is known to cause hemorrhagic cystitis, diarrhea, and conjunctivitis.Acute hemorrhagic cystitis in children is caused by adenoviruses types 11 and 21.The following table shows various syndromes caused by adenoviruses and associated serotypes:SyndromeRespiratory disease in childrenSore throat, febrile cold, pneumoniaARD in military recruitsFollicular (swimming pool) conjunctivitis/ Pharyngoconjunctival feverAdenovirus serotypes1, 2, 5, 63, 4, 7, 14, 214, 7, 213,7Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis (shipyard eye)8, 19, 37Diarrhea40, 41

questions.question: Viral infection mimicking erythroblastosis fetalis is:
questions.explanation: Parvovirus B19 infection mimics erythroblastosis fetalis.Parvovirus B19 is associated with:•Erythema infectiosum (fifth disease)• Transient aplastic crisis• Pure red cell aplasia.• Erythroblastosis fetalis (most commonly in early pregnancy)Picornavirus, Epstein-Barr virus, HSV infection do not mimic erythroblastosis fetalis.

questions.question: Which organism causes the disease shown below?
questions.explanation: The image showed a rash on the cheeks and face, with a slapped cheek appearance, characteristicof erythema infectiosum/ fifth disease. It is caused by Parvovirus B19.368Parvovirus B19 usually presents as a respiratory infection, with an erythematous maculopapularrash and arthralgia. The rash starts as prominent erythema of the cheek, popularly known asslapped-cheek appearance. The rash further spreads to the trunk and limbs followed bylymphadenopathy and arthralgia.It induces aplastic crisis in sickle cell anemia patients.Infection during pregnancy leads to non-immune fetal hydrops (highest risk in the first half ofgestational period).

questions.question: An 8-year-old child presents with skin lesions, suspected to be molluscum contagiosum. Howis the diagnosis of this condition typically made?
questions.explanation: Diagnosis of molluscum contagiosum is based on clinical appearance.Molluscum contagiosum manifests as pink pearly wart-like lesions with a characteristic dimple atthe center (umbilicated), not associated with inflammation and necrosis.Option B: Skin biopsy or smear of expressed material shows characteristic inclusion bodies but isnecessary only when the diagnosis is uncertain.Options A and C: Viral culture and PCR for viral DNA are not used for diagnosis.

questions.question: What is the causative organism of the condition shown below?
questions.explanation: The image shows condyloma acuminata. It is most commonly caused by Human papillomavirus(HPV) 6 and 11.Condyloma acuminata is a benign, genital wart which is a moist, soft, pedunculated wart found onthe external genitalia.Microscopically, the characteristic features include:369• A branching villous structure with connective tissue stroma⚫ Epidermis showing hyperkeratosis and acanthosis (thickening)••Cytoplasmic vacuolization of the squamous cells (koilocytosis) is characteristic of HPV infection.• No evident dysplasiaBranching villousstructures showingacanthosisKoilocytesOption A: Treponema pallidum can cause condylomata lata in secondary syphilis. It is smootherand flatter and may be associated with induration and ulceration. (image below)DOption C: Human papillomavirus 16 and 18 are associated with carcinoma of the cervix andanogenital region.Option D: Hemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid. Given below is the image of chancroid.370

questions.question: 357A patient presents with plantar warts as shown below. Which type of human papillomavirusis responsible for causing these?
questions.explanation: HPV types 1a, 57, and 27 accounts for most plantar warts.HPV 7 causes hand warts in butchers (butcher's warts).HPV 6 and 11 cause condyloma acuminata, sinonasal papilloma, and squamous papilloma of thelarynx.

questions.question: As a CHC medical officer, you organize an outreach program for HPV vaccination and theprevention of cervical cancer. Which protein is used for antigenic response in this vaccine?
questions.explanation: The HPV vaccines use virus-like particles (VLPs) that consist of the HPV L1 major capsid protein.The L1 protein self-assembles into VLPs when expressed in eukaryotic cells.These VLPs contain the same epitopes as the HPV virion. But they do not contain genetic materialand cannot transmit infection. The immunogenicity of the HPV vaccines relies on thedevelopment of conformational neutralizing antibodies to epitopes displayed on viral capsids.The nonavalent HPV vaccine works against strains 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52 and 58. It is usuallycommercialized in the name of Gardasil-9. It has received expanded indication which nowincludes the prevention of oropharyngeal and other head and neck cancers.HPV VaccineTypesQuadrivalent (Gardasil) 6, 11, 16, 18Bivalent (Cervarix)16, 18Nonavalent (Gardasil-9)6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58371

questions.question: Nonavalent HPV vaccine works against which of the following strains of the virus?
questions.explanation: The nonavalent HPV vaccine works against strains 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52 and 58. It is usuallycommercialized in the name of Gardasil-9. It has received expanded indication which nowincludes the prevention of oropharyngeal and other head and neck cancers.HPV VaccineTypesQuadrivalent (Gardasil)Bivalent (Cervarix)Nonavalent (Gardasil-9)6, 11, 16, 1816, 186, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58

questions.question: An HIV-positive patient presents with the following skin lesions. Which of the followingdiseases is associated with the virus implicated here?
questions.explanation: The above image showing red-purple macules and plaques in an HIV-positive patient is suggestiveof Kaposi sarcoma, caused by human herpesvirus 8. It also causes primary effusion lymphoma. Itis one of seven currently known human cancer viruses or oncoviruses.HHV-8 or Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) is known to cause Kaposi's sarcoma,in immunocompromised persons. Cancer patients receiving chemotherapy, AIDS patients, andorgan transplant recipients are all at a high risk of showing signs of infection.KSHV is a known causative agent of four diseases:••• Kaposi's sarcoma• KSHV-associated multicentric Castleman's disease (MCD)• Primary effusion lymphoma• KSHV inflammatory cytokine syndrome

questions.question: Which of the following viruses is implicated in progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy?
questions.explanation: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is caused by the JCvirus. JC virus-induced progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is one of the neurologicdiseases associated with HIV infection.Option B: BK virus is associated with nephropathy in transplant recipients.Option C: The long-term sequelae associated with measles infection is subacute sclerosingpanencephalitis.Option D: Herpes simplex virus causes temporal lobe encephalitis.372
